author: {'steamid': '76561198028441712', 'num_games_owned': 1349, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 1358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2184, 'last_played': 1413546054}
review:
[h1]86 / 100[/h1]

I've owned [b]Waves[/b] since its release in 2011 & I still come back to for a few rounds from time to time. My original review written back then was pretty hyped, basically chanting slogans like "I'm Hooked", "It's Uber!", "Grab it now!" [i](As you can tell, I was pretty impressed!)[/i]. 

In a retrospective [i](& more balanced)[/i] look, [b]Waves[/b] boasts solid mechanics, simple design & challenging arenas/modes. Don't be fooled by the simplicity though, this game is hardcore! The small circular [i]'Neo-Cyberspace'[/i] arena to navigate, along with the swiftly increasing viruses, bugs [i](& other strange spawners)[/i]  that trigger [i]wave after wave[/i] make this a true challenge to survive for any extended period. This difficulty can be off putting to some, but I really enjoy the intense gameplay - it keeps me coming back .. sweaty palms and all!

Being a twin-stick shooter you are obviously able to move & shoot independently on each analog stick, but in  Waves you also have a slow-mo [i]'Bullet Time'[/i] rechargeable power-up which gives you those split seconds needed to make an escape or clear some spawners when things just become too hectic. You can use this strategically to boost your scores too, such as getting a combo to enable your timed [i]'mega bomb'[/i] or get up close & double your points with the [i]'Point Blank'[/i] bonus. Movement & aiming are fluid & these additional tactical features become instinctive to use after a very short time playing.

Enemies are distinct, visually, clearly identifiable & have complementing attack moves. They have some cool mechanics, although you will learn there patterns before long [i](there aren't a lot of different enemies)[/i]. The sheer numbers in later waves & the combinations of enemies used negates their relative simplicity. When you experience these large number of enemies with the vast amount of effects & action happening on screen, it can be hard to keep track of your location. This is the only downside I have found overall, and is  really due to having such nice graphical effects [i](take the good with the bad I guess[/i] :) [i])[/i].

Of all the modes, the classic [b]Survival[/b] mode remains my favourite, although there are another six unique modes also available to tackle. Some are harder than others. There is the [b]Challenge[/b] mode offering unique puzzle like waves to clear, [b]Crunch Time[/b] offers short burst 3min timed runs & [b]Bombing Run[/b] where you have no guns, only bombs to  defend yourself with. Destroy the Cubes as quickly as possible in [b]Rush[/b], try the [i]‘Run'n'Gun’[/i] [b]Chase[/b] mode where you need to hit the spawning markers within 5 secs to continue & the newest mode call [b]Hold[/b] where you have a small moving circle to stay within to enable your weapons which I find perhaps the toughest of them all!

Below is straight gameplay footage of Survival mode -  A taste of what [b]Waves[/b] is like in action:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=325677941 
All these great modes, enemy types & overall challenge add up to a lot of replayability. When you wrap that up  in some smooth controls, gorgeous visual eye candy, pumping electro musical score [i](that has that tendency to get stuck in your head!)[/i], add online & friends leaderboards, a swag of interesting achievements & a big picture friendly design, you really have something special. You can see a lot of time has been put in to balance out, refine & improve the gameplay by the one-man development team @ [b]Squid In A Box[/b].

[b]Waves[/b] has held strong against the tide of new twin-stick shooter titles over the years, remaining one of the best available on Steam. If you missed this when it came out, it’s certainly worth a look now its half the price. It's great quality & great value!

Just as much fun to play now as it was when I got it!


[url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/TrueBlueReviews#curation]If you enjoyed reading this review, please follow [u]True Blue Reviews[/u] for more recommendations![/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197960410665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1322553600}
review: A spiritual sequel to the Geometry Wars games. It adds a bullet time feature for those flow-destroying tight spots, but it doesn't seem as claustrofobic as Geometry Wars; The enemy count goes up much, much slower and there doesn't seem to be any enemies designed to disrupt the player's routine. Even the Kudzu-style growths can easily be blasted through. The boss cube seems to be the only enemy type that needs to be avoided.

review:
My personal favorite twin-stick wave (ha) shooter. Beautiful and the time slowdown mechanic is a joy to use. RIP to the creator.

Fluid WASD + mouse controls, great graphics, fun chiptune soundtrack, and refined gameplay... this twin stick shooter basically does everything right. Even the menus are nice.
